thread.title: AL Division Series capsule: Blue Jays vs. Rangers
thread.title_full: AL Division Series capsule: Blue Jays vs. Rangers

title: AL Division Series capsule: Blue Jays vs. Rangers
text:
USA TODAY Sports' Bob Nightengale breaks down the American League field and gives his pick for the AL champion. USA TODAY Sports
David Price joined the Blue Jays at the trade deadline. (Photo: Jerome Miron, USA TODAY Sports)
CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE A capsule look at the American League Division Series between the Toronto Blue Jays and Texas Rangers:
(Times Eastern; *-if necessary):
Game 1 : Rangers (Yovani Gallardo, 13-11, 3.42 ERA) at Blue Jays (David Price, 18-5, 2.45 ERA), Thursday, 3:37, Fox Sports 1
Game 2 : Rangers (Cole Hamels, 13-8, 3.65) at Blue Jays (Marcus Stroman, 4-0, 1.67), Friday, 12:37, Fox Sports 1
Game 3 : Blue Jays (Marco Estrada, 13-8, 3.13) at Rangers (Derek Holland, 4-3, 4.91 ERA), Sunday, 8:10, Fox Sports 1
Game 4*: Blue Jays (R.A. Dickey, 11-11, 3.91) at Rangers (Colby Lewis, 17-9, 4.66, or Martin Perez, 3-6, 4.46), Monday, TBD
Game 5*: Rangers (Hamels) at Blue Jays (Price), Wednesday, TBD
***
USA TODAY
AL Division Series capsule: Astros vs. Royals
The case for the Rangers: Texas’ offense is less homer-heavy than Toronto’s, but since re-acquiring Mike Napoli, their lineup is as deep as any in baseball with players who have gap power and good on-base skills. Gallardo enters Game 1 with a 2.08 ERA, lowest among active starters with 25 postseason innings, and he went 2-0 with 132/3 shutout innings against Toronto this season. Hamels could start twice on regular rest in a five-game series; Texas has won his last 10 starts.
USA TODAY
Russell Martin, back in postseason, says Blue Jays 'feel like championship team'
The case for the Blue Jays: Toronto has baseball’s best offense — by far. The Jays’ 891 runs outpaced the third-place Rangers by 140, not to mention a 60-home run advantage, too, thanks largely to the triumvirate of Josh Donaldson, Jose Bautista and Edwin Encarnacion who all hit between 39 and 41 homers. They particularly mash against lefties, and Texas will start southpaws in three or four games. The midseason adds of Price and Stroman give Toronto some rotational firepower; the club is 13-2 in their outings this season.
The X factor: Blue Jays shortstop Troy Tulowitzki suffered a broken bone near his shoulder blade on Sept. 12, yet returned to action three weeks later, going 3-for-8 with a pair of doubles in two games at the end of the regular season. He’s a good defender with a career slugging percentage over .500, so it’s little wonder why the Jays are much better with him — 31-9 in his 40 starts — but if his lingering soreness affects his play or sidelines him, the light-hitting Cliff Pennington takes his lineup spot.
USA TODAY
The Walkoff Podcast: Previewing the ALDS between the Astros and Royals, Blue Jays and Rangers
Close and late: Both clubs rely on first-year closers, although the circumstances are different: The Rangers have 27-year-old Shawn Tolleson, who previously served as a set-up man for two seasons, whereas the Jays use 20-year-old rookie Roberto Osuna. He was brilliant through August but allowed has eight earned runs since Sept. 1, compared with 12 in the season’s first five months. Overall, Toronto, which traded for LaTroy Hawkins and Mark Lowe, has had the better bullpen performance, with a 3.48 ERA to Texas’ 4.09. Rangers rookie Keone Kela is their top set-up man but is pitching through soreness.
In the end: Toronto’s lineup is too potent, especially against lefty pitching, to be shut down by Texas. Blue Jays in 4
